pr_title: Add support for Network File Storage (NFS)

timeline.message:
Productize NFS (localfile) profile

The NFS profile allows PXF reading data from Network File Systems. The
NFS has to be mounted on every segment host where PXF is running from.
PXF will then read/write data from the mounted NFS file.

For NFS, the `pxf.fs.basePath` property must be set to a valid path. The
`pxf.fs.basePath` property represents the base path to be used for
tables accessing that server.

For example, if the `pxf.fs.basePath` property is set to `/mount/path`
and the external table definition is the following:

```sql
CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE nfs_table()
LOCATION ('pxf://path/to/data?PROFILE=nfs:avro&SERVER=nfs-server')
FORMAT 'CUSTOM' (formatter='pxfwritable_import');

Then PXF will use the :///mount/path/path/to/data URI to read AVRO
files.

In this commit, PXF also prevents relative paths to be specified in the
location of any of the hadoop-compatible file systems (S3, GS, HDFS,
NFS, etc). This is to prevent users from accessing data under relative
paths to the `basePath`. For example, assume the mount path above, a
malicious user can attempt to read data from `/etc/passwd` by creating
an external table like this:

```sql
CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE hack_etc_passwd (entry text)
LOCATION ('pxf://../../etc/passwd?PROFILE=nfs:text&SERVER=nfs')
FORMAT 'text';
```

PXF now prevents users from accessing relative paths in the path defined
in the LOCATION URI. PXF also prevents using `$` to disallow resolution
of environment variables for example:

```sql
CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE hack_home_dir (entry text)
LOCATION
('pxf://$HOME/secret-files-in-gpadmin-home?PROFILE=nfs:text&SERVER=nfs')
FORMAT 'text';
```

PXF now will throw an exception in cases where users attempt to use
relative paths or $ in the path.

Deprecate LOCALFILE

LOCALFILE is deprecated in favor of NFS

Add automation tests for NFS

Add multinode tests for NFS
Mount NFS on the running container, configure the NFS server on the cluster

timeline.bodyText: It looks like this check does not allow any occurrence of .. in the effective base path. This is probably the safest check to do, but doesn't it prevent the use of relative paths that stay within the configured base path, e.g. /mnt/data/dir1/../dir2?
timeline.author: bradfordb-vmware

replies.bodyText: it does, but we don't want to be super smart here as that location is reachable without using ..
replies.author: denalex

timeline.bodyText: You can have pathnames that contain $ that are not part of an environment variable. As long as we don't expand the path or pass it to a shell unescaped, we should be able to safely allow $ in paths, right?
timeline.author: bradfordb-vmware

replies.bodyText: yeah, but we are being conservative here. We make a big bet that nobody will actually have a path with $ in the path name.
